pr_title: Fetch certificate by alias in JSSKeyManager

timeline.message:
Fetch certificate by alias in JSSKeyManager

Expose functionality of CryptoManager in JSSKeyManager, allowing the
caller to fetch a certificate by alias (NSS DB's nickname).

Signed-off-by: Alexander Scheel <ascheel@redhat.com>

timeline.bodyText:
@edewata Is there a better exception here? The existing KeyManagers doesn't raise any exceptions, and this'll get called fairly early in the SSLEngine initialization (though, in Tomcat, that only happens when the first inbound connection occurs).
Thoughts?
timeline.author: cipherboy

replies.bodyText: I think the RuntimeException is fine. It's consistent with other methods and I don't have any better suggestion.

timeline.author: edewata

replies.bodyText:
We can't fix the type problem, so we should just choose one and stick with it.

Rabbit Hole
The difference between a org.mozilla.jss.crypto.X509Certificate and a java.security.cert.X509Certificate are that the former pre-dates the latter by a bit (~2 years). It also doesn't really contain much and is just an interface. PK11Cert -- where all of the magic happens -- implements both.
The other problem -- and the bigger reason why this wouldn't necessarily work - is that JSS's X509Certificate is an interface, but Java's X509Certificate is an abstract class.
So if we make X509Certificate a class and X509Certificate an interface... you get to figure out how to deal with everything. There's a couple of interfaces:

X509Certificate
InternalCertificate extends X509Certificate
TokenCertificate extends X509Certificate

You also have a couple of classes:

PK11Cert extends java.X509Certertificate implements jss.X509Certertificate
PK11InternalCert extends PK11Cert implements InternalCertificate

Interfaces can't extend abstract classes. So X509Certificate needs to be an abstract class. If you make that a class you have two options:

Either InternalCertificate and TokenCertificate remain interfaces, but drop the inheritance from jss.X509Certificate. This makes them less useful/powerful, but everything compiles. When you run tests, things seem to work in JSS. I'd bet money though, that we'd have to redo a lot of Dogtag PKI, because there's a bunch of references to InternalCertificate and TokenCertificate there.
Or we make InternalCertificate and TokenCertificate abstract classes as well. This doesn't work because PK11InternalCertificate extends PK11Cert and also implements InternalCertificate. A class can't extend from two parent classes, so we're stuck.

So 1 is the only viable approach, but would require extending everything to use concrete implementations (PK11InternalCertificate and PK11TokenCertificate) instead of interfaces. I'm not sure that's a good thing in general.
Coming out of the rabbit hole, we could make JSS's X509Certificate have the same signature as Java's, but I'm not sure that gets us anything.

My argument is that, since this method doesn't exist on Java's KeyManagers -- and we specifically want a JSSKeyManager instance in JSSEngine where this is used -- we should make this return a JSS X509Certificate, like I have. This lets us (most safely) cast to PK11Cert. There are other Java X509Certificate implementations, but only one core JSS X509Certificate implementation.
replies.author: cipherboy

replies.bodyText:
FWIW, my response to the second part of your comment is hidden in there:

There is only one core JSS X509Certificate implementation.

In other words, the cast from org.mozilla.jss.crypto.X509Certificate to PK11Cert is almost certainly safe. When we get such a c that isn't a PK11Cert, we want to know what object it is specifically (hence  + c on the log statement). I believe that information wouldn't be shown on the cast error, but I could be wrong.
